nodes.text: Human information processing has a limited capacity for absolute judgments and immediate memory (often near seven units), but this limit can be extended by using multiple dimensions, successive judgments, and recoding
Information theory maps amount of information to a dimensionless measure analogous to variance; transmitted information corresponds to input-output correlation
Absolute-judgment experiments treat the observer as a communication channel and measure channel capacity as asymptotic transmitted information when number of stimulus alternatives increases

Across unidimensional stimuli measured channel capacities range from about 1.6 to 3.9 bits with mean about 2.6 bits (~6.5 categories), suggesting a consistent limited span for simple sensory attributes
Pitch absolute-judgment (Pollack): transmitted information increases to an asymptote near 2.5 bits, corresponding to about six perfectly discriminable pitches
Loudness absolute-judgment (Garner): channel capacity about 2.3 bits, corresponding to about five discriminable intensity levels
Visual position and other unidimensional results: position 3.25-3.9 bits (10-15 positions); curvature as low as 1.6 bits; other measures cluster around mean 2.6 bits

Adding independently variable stimulus dimensions increases channel capacity but with diminishing returns; multi-attribute stimuli permit far greater identifiable categories than unidimensional stimuli

Multidimensional auditory experiments (Pollack & Ficks): six acoustic dimensions each with five values produced transmitted information of 7.2 bits (~150 categories); eight binary dimensions produced about 6.9 bits (~120 kinds)

Span of immediate memory is limited by a fixed number of chunks (about seven items), not by a fixed number of bits per item; memory span is approximately constant in items across different item-information values

Memory-span experiments (Hayes; Pollack): varying bits per item (binary, decimal, letters, words) showed span in items changes little while transmitted bits increase with bits per item, contradicting a constant-bits hypothesis

Subitizing: subjects accurately report up to five or six flashed dots without error; above that they estimate, implying a discontinuity between small-set accurate enumeration and larger-set estimation
Recoding (grouping or chunking) increases bits per chunk so that the fixed number of chunks in immediate memory can contain far more information; recoding is common (verbalization, mnemonics)
Smith recoding experiment: grouping binary digits into larger-base chunks (pairs, triples, etc.) and practicing the code increased recalled binary digits from 9 to as many as 40 after training

Conclusion: humans overcome informational bottlenecks by (a) making relative judgments, (b) increasing stimulus dimensionality (simultaneous discrimination), and (c) arranging successive absolute judgments (memory, sequences), with recoding as a key mechanism

Limitation and open question: it is unclear whether observed limits (e.g., number of distinctive phonetic features) are imposed by perceptual recognition systems or by signal production systems; suspected span of perceptual dimensionality near ten lacks objective evidence
